snp4.10:1.2.eng: is one said to be at peace?

snp4.10:1.3.eng: When asked, Gotama, please tell me

snp4.10:2.3.comm: “First beginning” is a technical term associated with speculative views about the beginnings of things. See note on DN 1:1.28.1.

snp4.10:2.5.eng: they are not governed by anything.
snp4.10:2.5.comm: Such as ignorance (AN 4.10:9.4) or craving (Dhp 342).

snp4.10:3.4.eng: truly that sage is controlled in speech.

snp4.10:4.1.eng: Rid of attachment to the future,

snp4.10:4.2.eng: they don’t grieve for the past.

snp4.10:4.3.eng: A seer of seclusion in the midst of contacts

snp4.10:4.4.eng: is not led astray among views.

snp4.10:6.4.comm: Agreeing with Norman that this is a rare instance of saddha in the sense of wish, desire, per Sanskrit śraddhā, one sense of which is “appetite”.

snp4.10:7.1.eng: Not training for desire for profit,

snp4.10:7.2.eng: nor getting annoyed at lack of profit;

snp4.10:7.3.eng: they are not hostile due to craving,

snp4.10:7.4.eng: for they are not greedy for flavors.

snp4.10:8.2.eng: they never conceive themselves in the world

snp4.10:8.3.eng: as equal, special, or less than;

snp4.10:9.2.eng: understanding the teaching, they are independent.

snp4.10:9.3.eng: No craving is found in them

snp4.10:9.4.eng: to continue existence or to end it.

snp4.10:10.1.eng: I declare them to be at peace,

snp4.10:10.3.eng: No ties are found in them,

snp4.10:11.1.eng: They have no children or livestock,

snp4.10:11.3.eng: No picking up or putting down
snp4.10:11.3.comm: As in Snp 4.3:8.3 this makes better sense considered as an active process.

snp4.10:12.1.eng: That by which one might describe

snp4.10:12.2.eng: an ordinary person or ascetics and brahmins

snp4.10:12.4.eng: which is why they’re unperturbed by words.

snp4.10:13.2.eng: a sage doesn’t speak of themselves as being

snp4.10:13.4.eng: One not prone to creation <j>does not return to creation.

snp4.10:14.1.eng: They who have nothing in the world of their own

snp4.10:14.2.eng: do not grieve for that which is not,

snp4.10:14.3.comm: Given the significance of “views” in the Aṭṭhakavagga, and that dhamma is commonly used in the sense of “teaching”, I read this in view of such passages as MN 47:14.3: dhammesu niṭṭhaṁ gacchati (“comes to a conclusion about the teachings”).

snp4.10:14.4.eng: that’s who is said to be at peace.”

snp4.11:1.1.eng: “Where do quarrels and disputes come from?

snp4.11:1.2.eng: And lamentation and sorrow, and stinginess?

snp4.11:1.3.eng: What of conceit and arrogance, and slander too—

snp4.11:1.4.eng: tell me please, where do they come from?”

snp4.11:2.1.eng: “Quarrels and disputes come from what we hold dear,
snp4.11:2.1.comm: Piya, “things held dear” or “what is liked”.

snp4.11:2.2.eng: as do lamentation and sorrow, stinginess,

snp4.11:2.4.eng: Quarrels and disputes are linked to stinginess,

snp4.11:2.5.eng: and when disputes have arisen there is slander.”

snp4.11:3.1.eng: “So where do things held dear <j>in the world spring from?

snp4.11:3.2.eng: And the lusts that are loose in the world?

snp4.11:3.3.eng: Where spring the hopes and aims

snp4.11:3.4.eng: a man has for the next life?”
snp4.11:3.4.comm: Samparāya means “in the next life”. The Niddesa’s gloss of “refuge, shelter” etc. does not change this but qualifies it: people look for safety in the next life.

snp4.11:4.1.eng: “What we hold dear in the world spring from desire,

snp4.11:4.2.eng: as do the lusts that are loose in the world.

snp4.11:4.3.eng: From there spring the hopes and aims

snp4.11:4.4.eng: a man has for the next life.”

snp4.11:5.1.eng: “So where does desire in the world spring from?

snp4.11:5.2.eng: And evaluations, too, where do they come from?

snp4.11:5.4.eng: and other things spoken of by the Ascetic?”

snp4.11:6.1.eng: “What they call pleasure and pain in the world—

snp4.11:6.2.eng: based on that, desire comes about.

snp4.11:6.3.eng: Seeing the manifestation and vanishing of forms,

snp4.11:6.4.eng: a personage makes evaluations in the world.

snp4.11:7.2.eng: these things are, too, when that pair is present.
snp4.11:7.2.comm: Here dvaya refers back to the “pair” of the previous lines and should not be overinterpreted as “duality”.

snp4.11:7.3.eng: One who is indecisive should train <j>in the path of knowledge;

snp4.11:7.4.eng: it is from knowledge <j>that the Ascetic speaks of these things.”

snp4.11:8.1.eng: “Where do pleasure and pain spring from?

snp4.11:8.2.eng: When what is absent do these things not occur?

snp4.11:8.3.eng: And also, on the topic of <j>manifesting and vanishing—

snp4.11:8.4.eng: tell me where they spring from.”

snp4.11:9.2.eng: when contact is absent they do not occur.

snp4.11:9.3.eng: And on the topic of <j>manifesting and vanishing—

snp4.11:9.4.eng: I tell you they spring from there.”

snp4.11:10.1.eng: “So where does contact in the world spring from?

snp4.11:10.2.eng: And possessions, too, where do they come from?

snp4.11:10.3.eng: When what is absent is there no possessiveness?

snp4.11:10.4.eng: When what vanishes do contacts not strike?”

snp4.11:11.3.eng: when wishing is absent there is no possessiveness;

snp4.11:11.4.eng: when form vanishes, contacts don’t strike.”

snp4.11:12.1.comm: The past participle sameta here is glossed by Niddesa as paṭipanna, i.e. “engaged in the practice”.

snp4.11:12.2.eng: And how do happiness and suffering vanish?

snp4.11:12.4.eng: I think we ought to know these things.”

snp4.11:13.1.comm: Visaññī is used of one whose perception is distorted by grief (Thig 6.2:1.2), by alcohol (Bu Pc 51:1.40), or by the four “distortions of perception” (AN 4.49:3.5). Saññasaññī is the opposite.

snp4.11:13.2.eng: not lacking perception, nor perceiving what has vanished.
snp4.11:13.2.comm: This verse answers the question of how one is to practice so that form disappears. It describes the process that leads from the fourth jhāna to the formless states.

snp4.11:13.3.eng: Form vanishes for one proceeding thus;

snp4.11:13.4.eng: for judgments due to proliferation spring from perception.”
snp4.11:13.4.comm: In MN 18, we have the sequence perception, thought, proliferation, then papañcasaññāsaṅkhā. This suggests that papañca causes saṅkhā, as per Bodhi.

snp4.11:14.1.eng: “Whatever I asked you have explained to me.
snp4.11:14.1.comm: Oddly, however, the disappearance of sukha and dukkha is not directly answered. It is, however, implied in the surmounting of 3rd jhāna.

snp4.11:14.2.eng: I ask you once more, please tell me this:

snp4.11:14.3.eng: Do some astute folk here say that this <j>is the highest extent

snp4.11:14.4.comm: While yakkha (Sanskrit yakṣa) is normally a worldly deity, he is identified with the ultimate Brahman at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 5.4.1 and Kena Upaniṣad 4.1.

snp4.11:14.5.eng: Or do they say it is something else?”

snp4.11:15.1.eng: “Some astute folk do say that this <j>is the highest extent
snp4.11:15.1.comm: At AN 10.29:20.2, the best of those who advocate the “ultimate purity of the spirit” are said to be those who teach the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, by which the Buddha is referring to the Brahmanical teacher Uddaka Rāmaputta (MN 26:16.13), said by the Buddha to be “astute” (paṇḍita MN 26:23.5).

snp4.11:15.3.eng: But some of them, claiming to be experts,
snp4.11:15.3.comm: Niddesa treats samaya as “stilling” (sama), in the sense of the cessation of a sentient being. The normal meaning is “occasion”, which fits well here. Niddesa and commentary explain this second class of so-called experts as the annihilationists.

snp4.11:15.4.eng: speak of an occasion when there is no residue.

snp4.11:16.1.eng: Knowing that these states are dependent,

snp4.11:16.2.eng: and knowing what they depend on, <j>the inquiring sage,

snp4.11:16.3.eng: having understood, is freed, and enters no dispute.

snp4.11:16.4.eng: The attentive do not proceed to life after life.”

snp4.12:0.2.eng: The Shorter Discourse on Arrayed For Battle

snp4.12:1.2.eng: those who are skilled disagree, arguing:

snp4.12:1.3.pli: Yo evaṃ jānāti sa vedi dhammaṃ,
snp4.12:1.3.eng: ‘Whoever sees it this way <j>understands the teaching;
snp4.12:1.3.comm: Here, as often in the Aṭṭhakavagga, jānāti implies different ways of knowing, which may be right or wrong (to degrees). We can “see” things differently, but we can’t “know” them differently.

snp4.12:1.4.eng: those who reject this are inadequate.’

snp4.12:2.2.eng: saying, ‘The other is a fool, an amateur!’

snp4.12:2.3.eng: Which one of these speaks true,

snp4.12:2.4.eng: for they all claim to be an expert?”

snp4.12:3.2.eng: makes you a useless fool lacking wisdom,
snp4.12:3.2.comm: Preferring omako over mago (“beast”), which seems harsh.

snp4.12:3.3.eng: then they’re all fools lacking wisdom,

snp4.12:3.4.eng: for they all maintain their own view.

snp4.12:4.1.eng: But if having your own view makes you pristine—

snp4.12:4.2.eng: pure in wisdom, expert and intelligent—

snp4.12:4.3.eng: then none of them lack wisdom,

snp4.12:4.4.eng: for such is the view they have all embraced.

snp4.12:5.1.eng: I do not say that it is correct
snp4.12:5.1.comm: I think “this is correct” refers, not to the assertion of a view, but to the assertion that the other is a fool. Niddesa takes it to mean the assertion of one of the 62 views, but this seems to be reading into the text.

snp4.12:5.2.eng: when they call each other fools.
snp4.12:5.2.comm: Here I take bālā as the quoted speech, as in the lines above and below. The commentary supplies the expected quotation indicator: ‘bālo’ti āhu. If we take bālā as subject of the verb here, per Bodhi, Norman, and Ñāṇadīpa, then the Buddha is adopting the reductive language of those he seeks to counter, obscuring the sense of the verse.

snp4.12:5.3.eng: Each has built up their own view to be the truth,
snp4.12:5.3.comm: It’s important to maintain the past sense of akaṁsu here: a view is something they have constructed and built up over time; it has solidified and become part of them, which is why it’s so hard to give up.

snp4.12:5.4.eng: which is why they take the other as a fool.”

snp4.12:6.1.eng: “What some say is true and correct,

snp4.12:6.2.eng: others say is hollow and false.

snp4.12:6.4.eng: why don’t ascetics say the same thing?”

snp4.12:7.1.eng: “The truth is one, there is no second,

snp4.12:7.2.eng: understanding which folk would not dispute.
snp4.12:7.2.comm: The readings and interpretation of this line is tricky; see discussions in Norman and Bodhi. Niddesa and Arthapada are in agreement, and I follow.

snp4.12:7.3.eng: But those ascetics each boast of different truths;

snp4.12:7.4.eng: that’s why they don’t say the same thing.”

snp4.12:8.1.eng: “But why do they speak of different truths,

snp4.12:8.2.eng: these proponents who claim to be skilled?

snp4.12:8.3.eng: Are there really so many different truths,

snp4.12:8.4.eng: or do they just follow their own lines of reasoning?”

snp4.12:9.1.eng: “No, there are not many different truths

snp4.12:9.2.eng: that, apart from perception, <j>are lasting in the world.
snp4.12:9.2.comm: The Niddesa glosses aññatra saññāya niccaggāhā, which is translated by Bodhi as “apart from the grasping of permanence by perception”. But this seems impossible to me: saññāya is an ablative constructed with aññatra, and niccāni surely agrees with saccāni. Further, the sense of this reading is a stretch, as we haven’t dealt with impermanence at all so far. I think the allusion is, rather, to the idea of dhammaniyāmatā, the “ﬁxity” or “regularity” of the Dhamma as an “eternal truth”.

snp4.12:9.3.eng: Having formed their reasoning <j>regarding different views,

snp4.12:9.4.eng: they say there are two things: true and false.

snp4.12:10.1.eng: The seen, heard, or thought, <j>or precepts or vows—
snp4.12:10.1.comm: This verse begins a rather striking pattern where the first couplet is essentially restated in the second couplet.

snp4.12:10.2.eng: based on these they show disdain.

snp4.12:10.4.eng: saying, ‘The other is a fool, an amateur!’

snp4.12:11.1.eng: They take the other as a fool on the same grounds
snp4.12:11.1.comm: Again the two couplets repeat the same meaning.

snp4.12:11.2.eng: that they speak of themselves as an expert.

snp4.12:11.3.eng: Claiming to be an expert on their own authority,

snp4.12:11.4.eng: they disdain the other while saying the same thing.

snp4.12:12.1.eng: They are perfect, <j>according to their own extreme view;

snp4.12:12.2.eng: drunk on conceit, imagining themselves proficient.

snp4.12:12.3.eng: They have anointed themselves in their own mind,

snp4.12:12.4.pli: Diṭṭhī hi sā tassa tathā samattā.
snp4.12:12.4.eng: for such is the view they have embraced.

snp4.12:13.1.eng: If the word of your opponent makes you deficient,

snp4.12:13.2.eng: then they too are lacking wisdom.

snp4.12:13.3.pli: Atha ce sayaṃ vedagū hoti dhīro,
snp4.12:13.3.eng: But if on your own authority you’re a knowledge master, an attentive one,
snp4.12:13.3.comm: This must refer back to the previous verse, where sayaṁ means “on one’s own account”.

snp4.12:13.4.eng: then there are no fools among the ascetics.

snp4.12:14.1.eng: ‘Those who proclaim a teaching other than this

snp4.12:14.2.eng: have fallen short of purity, and are inadequate’:

snp4.12:14.3.eng: so say each one of the sectarians,

snp4.12:14.4.eng: for they are deeply attached to their own view.

snp4.12:15.2.eng: denying that there is purification in other teachings.

snp4.12:15.3.eng: Thus each one of the sectarians, being dogmatic,

snp4.12:15.4.eng: speaks forcefully within the context <j>of their own journey.

snp4.12:16.1.eng: But in that case, so long as they are speaking forcefully <j>of their own journey,

snp4.12:16.2.eng: how can they take the other as a fool?

snp4.12:16.3.eng: They are the ones who provoke conflict

snp4.12:16.4.eng: when they call the other a fool <j>with an impure teaching.

snp4.12:17.1.eng: Standing in judgment, <j>measuring by their own standard,

snp4.12:17.2.eng: they dispute with the world more and more.
snp4.12:17.2.comm: Here uddhaṁ has the sense “further, all the more”.

snp4.12:17.3.eng: But a personage who has given up all judgments

snp4.12:17.4.eng: creates no conflict in the world.”
